intro: Dorotheanthus muirii, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble daisies. The plant produces vibrant orange to yellow flowers that bloom throughout the growing season, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for gardens and landscapes. Dorotheanthus muirii is also known for its ability to tolerate drought and poor soil conditions, enhancing its adaptability in various environments.
